query: Let $T=98721$, and let $K$ be the sum of the digits of $T$. Let $A_{n}$ be the number of ways to tile a $1 \times n$ rectangle using $1 \times 3$ and $1 \times 1$ tiles that do not overlap. Tiles of both types need not be used; for example, $A_{3}=2$ because a $1 \times 3$ rectangle can be tiled with three $1 \times 1$ tiles or one $1 \times 3$ tile. Compute the smallest value of $n$ such that $A_{n} \geq K$.
answers_list:
To solve the problem, we first need to calculate the sum of the digits of \( T = 98721 \).

Calculating the sum of the digits of \( 98721 \):
\[
9 + 8 + 7 + 2 + 1 = 27
\]
Thus, \( K = 27 \).

Next, we will compute \( A_n \), the number of ways to tile a \( 1 \times n \) rectangle using \( 1 \times 3 \) and \( 1 \times 1 \) tiles. We can set up a recurrence relation for \( A_n \).

### Recurrence Relation
- If we place a \( 1 \times 1 \) tile first, \( A_{n-1} \) ways remain for the rest of the \( 1 \times (n-1) \) rectangle.
- If we place a \( 1 \times 3 \) tile first (which is possible only if \( n \geq 3 \)), \( A_{n-3} \) ways remain for the rest of the \( 1 \times (n-3) \) rectangle.

Thus, the recurrence relation can be written as:
\[
A_n = A_{n-1} + A_{n-3}
\]

### Base Cases
To use this recurrence, we need to establish some base cases:
- \( A_0 = 1 \): There is one way to tile a \( 1 \times 0 \) rectangle (doing nothing).
- \( A_1 = 1 \): One way to tile a \( 1 \times 1 \) rectangle (using one \( 1 \times 1 \) tile).
- \( A_2 = 1 \): One way to tile a \( 1 \times 2 \) rectangle (using two \( 1 \times 1 \) tiles).
- \( A_3 = 2 \): Two ways to tile a \( 1 \times 3 \) rectangle (three \( 1 \times 1 \) tiles or one \( 1 \times 3 \) tile).

Now we can calculate more values of \( A_n \):

\[
\begin{align*}
A_4 & = A_3 + A_1 = 2 + 1 = 3 \\
A_5 & = A_4 + A_2 = 3 + 1 = 4 \\
A_6 & = A_5 + A_3 = 4 + 2 = 6 \\
A_7 & = A_6 + A_4 = 6 + 3 = 9 \\
A_8 & = A_7 + A_5 = 9 + 4 = 13 \\
A_9 & = A_8 + A_6 = 13 + 6 = 19 \\
A_{10} & = A_9 + A_7 = 19 + 9 = 28 \\
A_{11} & = A_{10} + A_8 = 28 + 13 = 41 \\
A_{12} & = A_{11} + A_9 = 41 + 19 = 60 \\
A_{13} & = A_{12} + A_{10} = 60 + 28 = 88 \\
A_{14} & = A_{13} + A_{11} = 88 + 41 = 129 \\
A_{15} & = A_{14} + A_{12} = 129 + 60 = 189 \\
A_{16} & = A_{15} + A_{13} = 189 + 88 = 277 \\
A_{17} & = A_{16} + A_{14} = 277 + 129 = 406 \\
A_{18} & = A_{17} + A_{15} = 406 + 189 = 595 \\
A_{19} & = A_{18} + A_{16} = 595 + 277 = 872 \\
A_{20} & = A_{19} + A_{17} = 872 + 406 = 1278 \\
A_{21} & = A_{20} + A_{18} = 1278 + 595 = 1873 \\
A_{22} & = A_{21} + A_{19} = 1873 + 872 = 2745 \\
A_{23} & = A_{22} + A_{20} = 2745 + 1278 = 4023 \\
A_{24} & = A_{23} + A_{21} = 4023 + 1873 = 5896 \\
A_{25} & = A_{24} + A_{22} = 5896 + 2745 = 8641 \\
A_{26} & = A_{25} + A_{23} = 8641 + 4023 = 12664 \\
A_{27} & = A_{26} + A_{24} = 12664 + 5896 = 18560 \\
A_{28} & = A_{27} + A_{25} = 18560 + 8641 = 27101 \\
A_{29} & = A_{28} + A_{26} = 27101 + 12664 = 39765 \\
A_{30} & = A_{29} + A_{27} = 39765 + 18560 = 58325 \\
\end{align*}
\]

### Finding the Minimum \( n \)
We now find the smallest \( n \) such that \( A_n \geq 27 \):
- \( A_0 = 1 \)
- \( A_1 = 1 \)
- \( A_2 = 1 \)
- \( A_3 = 2 \)
- \( A_4 = 3 \)
- \( A_5 = 4 \)
- \( A_6 = 6 \)
- \( A_7 = 9 \)
- \( A_8 = 13 \)
- \( A_9 = 19 \)
- \( A_{10} = 28 \)

Here, \( A_{10} = 28 \) is the first value that meets or exceeds \( K = 27 \).

Therefore, we conclude with the final answer:

[Final Answer] The answer is 10 \n#### 10
